subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Example phrases using keyboard mapping proposals

messageBody:
On 6.1.2008 Ted Larson Freeman wrote:
> Here are a few phrases (due, in order, to: Jefferson et
> al., Shaw, Seuss, Wolfe and Pasternak) to illustrate some
> of the choices we are considering with the various
> keyboard mapping proposals:
>
[snip]

FWIW speakers in England[^1] consider #33 a long vowel, and
rightly so, since it is phonetically long in their accents.

I'm glad to be able to say that I find BPJ2 the most
readable of the examples.

When seeing the other examples, Jerome and QS-SAMPA in
particular, I feel confirmed in mapping lowercase {q} to the
most infrequent of the English vowels. Infrequency and
similarity to _oy_ conspire to make #35 the best mapping for
_q_, although it would not be infrequent in a text about
{bqZ distrqiG kqNZ}! I agree that it is probably better to
write the {i} when _-ing_ comes after a vowel.

I'm not very troubled by _G_ for #21, and I don't think my
acquaintance with Greek where gamma is the regular spelling
for that sound has much to do with it. On the other hand I
find _M_ for alt #23 very disturbing. It seems _M_ is more
labial than nasal to my sensibilities! I guess it boils down
to that _G_ is part of the TO spelling of #21, but _M_ is
never used to spell #23 in TO, and I like to avoid such
mappings as far as #possible.

B for #37 is a weak point in BPJ2. I wonder if it would be
better if {B} be mapped to #40 and {U} to #37? Uppercase _B_
rotated ninety degrees looks like the digraph _oo_, while
_U_ is part of the digraph _OU_, and moreover {u} for #36
and {U} for #37 would form a pair. Hopefully not {u bBt iN D
fBlZ mUT}! I'm anxious to hear what others think, since my
knowledge of Old English and other related languages which
have not gone through the */u:/ > /aU/ change may lead me
astray into finding {hU z yr hUs iN tUn} easy to read. There
are not, I think, many minimal pairs between #37 and #40.

To be sure {U} for #37 works less well in those words where
TO has _ow_, but it can't be helped. The similarity between
a rotated _B_ and oo is perhaps also not as helpful to
native speakers as I hope. I fear that the _B_ -- _oo_
similarity falls flat, or even is disastrous, for the many
words where #40 or #17+#40 corresponds to _u, ue, ui, ew eu,
eau_, like {fyB hyBmEN byBtiZ r fBld bY kyBt dyBRZ/dBRZ iN
syBts}. Of course such conglomerations will occur but
seldom, and I think one will soon learn to recognise the
combination {yB}, so that it will fire the right neurons.

BTW, since QS allows us to spell foreign names like _Panama_
and _Tierra del Fuego_ more close to the right pronunciation
rather than with the mispronunciation induced by applying
English TO rules on the foreign spellings, shouldn't we do
so, writing {`pAnAmA n tyerA del fwegQ} rather than {`pancmA
n `tieru del fVEgO}? These are not the worst examples: the
CMUPD records atrocious mispronunciations of Russian names
which have arisen from unfamiliarity with both the
transliteration system and Russian pronunciation rules; I
daresay there is not a single Russian name in the CMUPD for
which the correct pronunciation is recorded! This is in
contrast with the LPD which carefully notes the native
pronunciation of foreign names.

{beGkt fIlip yVnsQn}

[^1]: The ambiguity of "English" when speaking of accents in
England and around the world is really annoying. IMHO the
tautological "English English" is hardly satisfying. Swedish
distinguishes between "finsk" 'pertaining to the Finnish
language and its speakers' and "finländsk" 'pertaining to
the country Finland and its citizens'. The distinction is
helpful as there are large minorities of Swedish speakers in
Finland and Finnish speakers in Sweden. As yet we have no
similar distinction on the Swedish side, but it surely is
needed! In actual practice "finlandssvensk" is more current
than "finländsk" when speaking of language, but
"sverigesvensk" doesn't exist, and since "English English"
is what we want to avoid it is tempting to coin a word
"Englandish" or "Englandic". Although unwont it is not
unwanted! "Irelandish" or "Irelandic" may be similarly used
to refer to English as spoken in Ireland, since "Irish"
refers to the Celtic language of that island.

/BP 8^)>
--
Benct Philip Jonsson -- melroch atte melroch dotte se
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
No man forgets his original trade: the rights of
nations and of kings sink into questions of grammar,
if grammarians discuss them.
-Dr. Samuel Johnson (1707 - 1784)
